messages: 878b627b013f0c465ec2be26325ce80d (18:18): vimgor: anti-match pattern
878b627b013f0c465ec2be26325ce80d (18:33): nope. [] is a character class. that says "match any single character that is not one of the following literal characters: . [ f o"
9351c00f73660c0a9076d185506e355f (18:34): ^.[foo]. means dont atch string foo
fb2c4f3e688db2a676f292cd15961a59 (18:34): pks: no it doesn't
878b627b013f0c465ec2be26325ce80d (18:35): [] is a character class
878b627b013f0c465ec2be26325ce80d (18:35): emphasis on character
9351c00f73660c0a9076d185506e355f (18:35): no this means dont match string foo
fb2c4f3e688db2a676f292cd15961a59 (18:35): jamessan: actually that's an entirely illegal expression, isn't it? Due to the non-matching ] ?
878b627b013f0c465ec2be26325ce80d (18:35): Zathrus: you may have to escape that trailing ], yeah
878b627b013f0c465ec2be26325ce80d (18:35): pks: is that POSIX or vim regex?
9351c00f73660c0a9076d185506e355f (18:36): you were talking about vim stuff
9351c00f73660c0a9076d185506e355f (18:36): i should notice that sicne we are on #vim :)
fb2c4f3e688db2a676f292cd15961a59 (18:43): I'm still pretty sure that's invalid POSIX syntax...
9351c00f73660c0a9076d185506e355f (18:43): at least not to man 7 regex
fb2c4f3e688db2a676f292cd15961a59 (18:43): ( is grouping, not [
9351c00f73660c0a9076d185506e355f (18:43): inside [] it is used for grouping
878b627b013f0c465ec2be26325ce80d (18:43): he's not trying to do grouping
9351c00f73660c0a9076d185506e355f (18:44): but only if there is speccial char after [ like . or < or =
9351c00f73660c0a9076d185506e355f (18:44): each have its own meaning
fb2c4f3e688db2a676f292cd15961a59 (18:44): pks: ah, ok I see now.
fb2c4f3e688db2a676f292cd15961a59 (18:45): the regex(7) man page is in desperate need of some decent formatting, but you are quite correct.

9351c00f73660c0a9076d185506e355f (18:45): ``Within a bracket expression, a collating element (a character, a multi-character sequence that collates as if  it were  a  single  character,  or  a  collating-sequence  name for either) enclosed in `[.' and `.]' stands for the sequence of characters of that collating element''
9351c00f73660c0a9076d185506e355f (18:45): yeap, it needs reformating
878b627b013f0c465ec2be26325ce80d (18:45): actually, it looks like [[.foo.]] matches f, fo, or foo
878b627b013f0c465ec2be26325ce80d (18:46): oh, I read an example wrong
fb2c4f3e688db2a676f292cd15961a59 (18:46): nope, [. and .] are special operators inside of [ ]
878b627b013f0c465ec2be26325ce80d (18:46): Zathrus: yeah, I know that. I was questioning their behavior
fb2c4f3e688db2a676f292cd15961a59 (18:48): jamessan: the phrase "collates as if it were a single character" indicates to me that it's all-or-nothing
878b627b013f0c465ec2be26325ce80d (18:48): Zathrus: yeah, I just misread the example they gave
fb2c4f3e688db2a676f292cd15961a59 (18:48): the formatting is awful and the wording is not much better.
fb2c4f3e688db2a676f292cd15961a59 (18:48): but, hey, it was designed by committee...
9351c00f73660c0a9076d185506e355f (18:49): Zathrus: at least, everything written there holds
c3c31ae67404d89834d5432b28c5e99f (18:54): how can i set vim to use tabs for intendation?
c3c31ae67404d89834d5432b28c5e99f (18:54): i mean for autointend etc
12f14b72c1c64723146164dd4fe0b6a9 (18:55): set noexpandtab

1c26c5565e82edd3b6cbf47766a7c2cd (19:06): How can I get VIM to run a script whenever I press backspace or delete in Insert mode and then check the character I'm about to delete and decide whether to do something special?
1c26c5565e82edd3b6cbf47766a7c2cd (19:07): Actually, the character I'm about to delete as well as the one after it either in the forward direction (for delete) or reverse (for backspace).
4969e383a78d3407b54160eb0de4b90b (19:08): (but... dude.. that's crazy.. what _are_ you doing?)
1c26c5565e82edd3b6cbf47766a7c2cd (19:10): I shall explain.
1c26c5565e82edd3b6cbf47766a7c2cd (19:10): Yesterday I added a couple of rules to auto-complete surrounding characters like quotes and brackets for me.
1c26c5565e82edd3b6cbf47766a7c2cd (19:10): A la TextMate.
1c26c5565e82edd3b6cbf47766a7c2cd (19:11): So when I type a ' it goes and adds '' and puts the cursor between them.
1c26c5565e82edd3b6cbf47766a7c2cd (19:11): Great.
1c26c5565e82edd3b6cbf47766a7c2cd (19:11): But if I do it accidentally, I want delete to delete both of them.
1c26c5565e82edd3b6cbf47766a7c2cd (19:11): A la TextMate.
4969e383a78d3407b54160eb0de4b90b (19:11): Sounds like it might get annoying...
4969e383a78d3407b54160eb0de4b90b (19:12): Can you type   don't  correctly?
1c26c5565e82edd3b6cbf47766a7c2cd (19:12): The only thing that's annoying for me so far is when I'm typing a comment and I use an apostrophe and it adds two.
1c26c5565e82edd3b6cbf47766a7c2cd (19:12): Right, that's the only problem.
1c26c5565e82edd3b6cbf47766a7c2cd (19:12): But for brackets and parentheses and double quotes it's great.
4969e383a78d3407b54160eb0de4b90b (19:12): Do you do any programming with that?
1c26c5565e82edd3b6cbf47766a7c2cd (19:12): PHP all day long :P
4969e383a78d3407b54160eb0de4b90b (19:12): printf("My name is \"%s\"", name);  <== would also get annoying..
4969e383a78d3407b54160eb0de4b90b (19:13): \" would have to insert another \" to close it
1c26c5565e82edd3b6cbf47766a7c2cd (19:13): That's not as bad as you might think.
1c26c5565e82edd3b6cbf47766a7c2cd (19:13): You type \" and it adds \"" but your cursor is between them.
1c26c5565e82edd3b6cbf47766a7c2cd (19:13): So type %s\
1c26c5565e82edd3b6cbf47766a7c2cd (19:14): Anyway, it's pretty convenient for me; I'd gotten used to it.
878b627b013f0c465ec2be26325ce80d (19:14): *shudder* that's the editor getting to involved for my taste :)
1c26c5565e82edd3b6cbf47766a7c2cd (19:15): When you have to type $_SESSION['something'] over and over and over, it becomes convenient to type ses<C-]>['
1c26c5565e82edd3b6cbf47766a7c2cd (19:15): I also mapped ses to type out $_SESSION
1c26c5565e82edd3b6cbf47766a7c2cd (19:15): Er, with autocomplete.
1c26c5565e82edd3b6cbf47766a7c2cd (19:15): Not a mapping per se.
cae6af6dbbae6f8fd4ffe04a3fa82fea (19:28): Why does this command RemoveTrailingWhitespacesInLinesWithContent :%s/[^ \t]\@<=[ \t]\+$//
cae6af6dbbae6f8fd4ffe04a3fa82fea (19:29): also remove lines containing only tabs /spaces?
cae6af6dbbae6f8fd4ffe04a3fa82fea (19:29): When using /
cae6af6dbbae6f8fd4ffe04a3fa82fea (19:30): to search for this pattern I only the whitespaces after some content is matched..

276517635a68b36108cbb10a41749109 (19:32): While using many windows in vim, I often want to make the current window as large as possible. Now i use the mouse to arrange the other windows. But I would like a function to "inflate" the current window automatically. Anyone have a clue? :)
878b627b013f0c465ec2be26325ce80d (19:34): Ninny: :he window-resize  for other ways to resize windows
8100f6e86812e47cd5aff0cad674f8c2 (19:35): can anyone tell me how to add a [tab] ident to certain lines?
a6af29dc5df2b24efb0c6d14ffb6f23a (19:36): victor: :he >
8100f6e86812e47cd5aff0cad674f8c2 (19:37): so something like: :>32,45
878b627b013f0c465ec2be26325ce80d (19:38): range comes first
8100f6e86812e47cd5aff0cad674f8c2 (19:38): awesome, thanks. :)
b53a6cd297cf4b31412e5fda9a95fb18 (19:55): Hi, how do I let 'vsplit' open the new file in the right window, not the left window?
